Authors: Zegota H.
Title: The effect of γ-irradiation on citrus pectin in N2O and N2O/O2 saturated aqueous solutions
Affiliations: Inst. of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Tech. Univ., W., Lodz, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Zegota, H., Inst. of Applied Radiation Chemistry, Tech. Univ., W., Lodz, Poland
Abstract: Radiolytic depolymerization of citrus pectin in 1% aqueous solutions saturated with N2O or N2O/O2 (4:1) gas mixture was investigated. The decrease in the intrinsic viscosity, changes in the average molecular weight distribution and the increase in the concentration of chain breaks in pectin molecules after irradiation was accompanied by the increase in the content of reducing (carbonyl) groups and the decrease in pH and gelling strength. In the presence of dissolved oxygen the radiation induced changes in pectin solutions were enhanced. Radical species stabilized in frozen matrix of pectin polycrystalline ices irradiated at 77 K were recorded by ESR measurements. During thermal annealing of polycrystalline sample trapped radicals became reactive due to microscopic displacement of solvent molecules. In the presence of oxygen the formation of carbohydrate peroxyl radicals was confirmed and their spectra were recorded at temperatures of 200-220 K. Possible mechanism of pectin macromolecules degradation based on the rearrangement of radicals localized at C(5)-carbon atom in the pyranose ring of galacturonic acid residue is discussed.
Index Keywords: Citrus

Authors: Zerlauth A.
Title: Air quality management systems in urban regions: An analysis of RECLAIM in Los Angeles and its transferability to Vienna
Affiliations: Interdisc. Inst. of Environ. E., Vienna Univ. of Econ. and Bus. A., Althanstr. 51, Vienna 1190, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Zerlauth, A., Interdisc. Inst. of Environ. E., Vienna Univ. of Econ. and Bus. A., Althanstr. 51, Vienna 1190, Austria
Abstract: The discussion of how to manage air quality in an era of shrinking public budgets and the trend towards deregulation has led to a rethinking of the present system in the urban region of Vienna. This paper is an attempt to contribute to these considerations by a comparative study of the 'Command-and-Control' type of system operative in Austria and the new tradable emissions permit approach introduced in the urban region of Los Angeles, California (the so-called 'RECLAIM' program). The study utilized a survey of companies included in the respective pollution control programs in L.A. and Vienna, and a survey of experts and administrators.

Authors: Zhang J., Smith K.R.
Title: Emissions of carbonyl compounds from various cookstoves in China
Affiliations: Environ. and Occup. Hlth. Sci. Inst., UMDNJ-Robert Wood Johnson Med. Sch., Rutgers University, 170 Frelinghuysen Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States; Program on Environment, East-West Center, 1777 East-West Road, Honolulu, HI 96848, United States; Ctr. for Occup. and Environ. Health, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, J., Environ. and Occup. Hlth. Sci. Inst., UMDNJ-Robert Wood Johnson Med. Sch., Rutgers University, 170 Frelinghuysen Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States, Program on Environment, East-West Center, 1777 East-West Road, Honolulu, HI 96848, United States; Smith, K.R., Program on Environment, East-West Center, 1777 East-West Road, Honolulu, HI 96848, United States, Ctr. for Occup. and Environ. Health, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a new database of carbonyl emission factors for commonly used cookstoves in China. The emission factors, reported both on a fuel-mass basis (mg/kg) and on a defined cooking-task basis (mg/task), were determined using a carbon balance approach for 22 types of fuel/stove combinations. These include various stoves (e.g., traditional, improved, brick, and metal, with and without flue) using different species of crop residues and wood, kerosene, and several types of coals and gases. The results show that all the tested cookstoves produced formaldehyde and acetaldehyde and that the vast majority of the biomass stoves produced additional carbonyl compounds such as acetone, acrolein, propionaldehyde, crotonaldehyde, 2-butanone, isobutyraldehyde, butyraldehyde, isovaleraldehyde, valeraldehyde, hexaldehyde, benzaldehyde, o-tolualdehyde, m,p-tolualdehyde, and 2,4-dimethylbenzaldehyde. Carbonyls other than formaldehyde and acetaldehyde, however, were rarely generated by burning coal, coal gas, and natural gas. Kerosene and LPG stoves generated more carbonyl compounds than coal, coal gas, and natural gas stoves, but less than biomass stoves. Indoor levels of carbonyl compounds for typical village houses during cooking hours, estimated using a mass balance model and the measured emission factors, can be high enough to cause acute health effects documented for formaldehyde exposure, depending upon house parameters and individuals' susceptibility.

Authors: Zhang J., Rao S.T.
Title: The role of vertical mixing in the temporal evolution of ground-level ozone concentrations
Affiliations: Dept. of Earth and Atmosph. Sciences, University at Albany, State University of New York, Albany, NY, United States; Office of Science and Technology, New York Stt. Dept. Environ. C., 50 Wolf Road, Albany, NY 12233-3259, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, J., Dept. of Earth and Atmosph. Sciences, University at Albany, State University of New York, Albany, NY, United States; Rao, S.T., Dept. of Earth and Atmosph. Sciences, University at Albany, State University of New York, Albany, NY, United States, Office of Science and Technology, New York Stt. Dept. Environ. C., 50 Wolf Road, Albany, NY 12233-3259, United States
Abstract: Aircraft measurements taken during the North American Research Strategy for Tropospheric Ozone-Northeast field study reveal the presence of ozone concentration levels in excess of 80 ppb on a regional scale in the nocturnal residual layer during ozone episodes. The air mass containing increased concentrations of ozone commonly is found on a horizontal spatial scale of about 600 km over the eastern United States. The diurnal variation in ozone concentrations at different altitudes, ozone flux measurements, and vertical profiles of ozone suggest that ozone and its precursors trapped aloft in the nocturnal residual layer can influence the ground-level ozone concentrations on the following day as the surface-based inversion starts to break up. A simple one-dimensional model, treating both meteorological and chemical processes, has been applied to investigate the relative contributions of vertical mixing and photochemical reactions to the temporal evolution of the ground-level ozone concentration during the daytime. The results demonstrate that the vertical mixing process contributes significantly to the ozone buildup at ground level in the morning as the mixing layer starts to grow rapidly. When the top of the mixing layer reaches the ozone-rich layer aloft, high ozone concentrations are brought down into the mixing layer, rapidly increasing the ground-level ozone concentration because of fumigation. As the mixing layer grows further, it contributes to dilution while the chemical processes continue to contribute to ozone production. Model simulations also were performed for an urban site with different amounts of reduction in the ground-level emissions as well as a 50% reduction in the concentration levels of ozone and its precursors aloft. The results reveal that a greater reduction in the ground-level ozone concentration can be achieved by decreasing the concentrations of ozone and precursors aloft than can be achieved from a reduction of local emissions. Given the regional extent of the polluted dome aloft during a typical ozone episode in the northeastern United States, these results demonstrate the necessity and importance of implementing emission reduction strategies on the regional scale; such regionwide emission controls would reduce effectively the long-range transport of pollutants in the Northeast.
Index Keywords: ozone; temporal evolution; vertical mixing; North America

Authors: Zhang J., Kong Z.
Title: Study on vegetation and climate changes in Beijing region since Late Pleistocene
Affiliations: Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100029, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, J., Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100029, China; Kong, Z., Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100029, China
Abstract: A complex history of the Late Pleistocene vegetation and environmental changes for the northern part of the deciduous forest is revealed in an exceptionally well - dated pollen diagram from Dongganchi in Beijing area. In 15 800 - 14 700 a B.P., the arbors and aquatic plants were sparse, and the climate was cold and dry. In 14 700 - 13 400 a B.P., forest growth was limited, it was dominated by conifers, presumably in responded to a cooling climate. Aquatic plants became abundant. During 13 400 to 12 600 a B.P., there was a widespread development of coniferous and broad-leaved mixed forest, aquatic plants decreased which corresponded to climate gradually becoming warming and dry. In 12 600 - 11 400 a B.P., there was alternation of coniferous and broad-leaved mixed forest, so were aquatic plants. From 11 400 to 9 600 a B.P., the decreasing of trees and increasing of herbs and shrubs suggested an opening up of the vegetation in responded to cooling, probably corresponded to Younger Dryas from 10 600 to 10 300 a B.P. About 9600 - 7270 a B.P., the climate changed from cooler and dry to warmer and humid. About 7270 - 3390 a B.P., the coniferous and the broad-leaved mixed forest increased, it was in responding to the 'climatic optimum'. About 3390 - 1000 a B.P., climate became cooler and dry. After 1000 a B.P., there was a severe fluctuation, indicating the temperature drop and the environmental deterioration.
Author Keywords: Beijing; Climate change; Late Pleistocene; Pollen analysis; Vegetation change
Index Keywords: climate change; Pleistocene; pollen; vegetation cover; Beijing; China

Authors: Zhang J., Smith K.R., Uma R., Ma Y., Kishore V.V.N., Lata K., Khalil M.A.K., Rasmussen R.A., Thorneloe S.T.
Title: Carbon monoxide from cookstoves in developing countries: 1. Emission factors
Affiliations: Environ. and Occup. Hlth. Sci. Inst., Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, Rutgers University, 170 Frelinghuysen Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States; Program on Environment, East-West Center, Honolulu, HI, United States; University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States; Tata Energy Research Institute, New Delhi, India; Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Portland State University, Portland, OR, United States; Oregon Grad. Inst., Robert Wood Johnson Medical School, Rutgers University, 170 Frelinghuysen Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States, Program on Environment, East-West Center, Honolulu, HI, United States; Smith, K.R., Program on Environment, East-West Center, Honolulu, HI, United States, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States; Uma, R., Tata Energy Research Institute, New Delhi, India; Ma, Y., Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Kishore, V.V.N., Tata Energy Research Institute, New Delhi, India; Lata, K., Tata Energy Research Institute, New Delhi, India; Khalil, M.A.K., Portland State University, Portland, OR, United States; Rasmussen, R.A., Oregon Grad. Inst. Sci. and Technol., Beaverton, OR, United States; Thorneloe, S.T., US Environmental Protection Agency, Research Triangle Park, NC, United States
Abstract: Cookstoves in developing countries are individually small, but so numerous that, depending on emission factors, they could be significant influences on global and regional carbon monoxide (CO) inventories. This paper presents a new database of CO emission factors for commonly used cookstoves in developing countries. The emission factors were determined using a carbon balance approach for 56 types of fuel/stove combinations in China and India. These include various stoves (e.g., traditional, improved, mud, brick, and metal, with and without chimney) using animal dung, different species of crop residues and wood, root fuel, charcoal, kerosene, and several types of coals and gases. The chosen fuel/stove combinations represent a large fraction of the total in developing countries. Thus, the database can be used to improve estimates of CO emission inventories. The CO emission factors ranged widely, from 3.0 × 10-2 g/kg for the coal gas/traditional stove to 2.8 × 102 g/kg for the charcoal/Angethi stove, nearly 4 orders of magnitude. Since stove efficiencies and fuel energy contents were measured simultaneously, CO emission factors on the basis of a standard cooking task (energy delivered) were also determined and reported in this paper. Task-based emission factors are particularly useful for comparing the air pollution potential of different fuel/stove combinations and assessing the impacts of substitutions. © 1999 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Biomass fuels; Carbon monoxide; Cookstoves; Developing countries; Emission factors; Fossil fuels

Authors: Zhang Z.X.
Title: Should the rules of allocating emissions permits be harmonised?
Affiliations: Faculties of Law and Economics, University of Groningen, P.O. Box 716, 9700 AS Groningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Z.X., Faculties of Law and Economics, University of Groningen, P.O. Box 716, 9700 AS Groningen, Netherlands
Abstract: The Kyoto Protocol is the first international environmental agreement that sets legally binding greenhouse gas emissions targets and timetables for Annex I countries. Its Article 17 authorizes emissions trading among Annex B countries. If properly designed, emissions trading can effectively reduce their abatement costs, while assisting Annex I countries in achieving their Kyoto obligations. If Annex B governments elect to allocate the assigned amounts to their individual sub-national legal entities and authorize them to trade on the international emissions permits market, I argue that individual governments should be left free to devise their own ways of allocating emissions permits.
Author Keywords: Carbon tax; Emissions trading; Greenhouse gases; International competitiveness
Index Keywords: climate change; emissions trading; environmental economics; pollution tax

Authors: Zhou W., Ye S.-H.
Title: Subchronic oral methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE) exposure in male Sprague-Dawley rats and effects on health of MTBE exposed workers
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Health, Shanghai Medical University, Shanghai 200032, China; Department of Environmental Health, Shanghai Medical University, 138 Yi Xue Yuan Road, Shanghai, 200032, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, W., Department of Environmental Health, Shanghai Medical University, Shanghai 200032, China, Department of Environmental Health, Shanghai Medical University, 138 Yi Xue Yuan Road, Shanghai, 200032, China; Ye, S.-H., Department of Environmental Health, Shanghai Medical University, Shanghai 200032, China
Abstract: Methyl tertiary-butyl ether (MTBE) is used to reduce carbon monoxide and ozone in urban air and to boost fuel octane. There are yet no data on the toxicity and health effects of MTBE in China. To evaluate the possible toxicity of domestic MTBE, 40 male, 8-week-old Sprague-Dawley rats, weighing 180-200 g, were gavaged with different concentrations of MTBE. MTBE, dissolved in soybean oil, was administered at doses of 1000, 600 or 200 mg/kg b.w., and a control group with soybean oil, once daily, five days per week, for 90 days. There were no marked differences in body weight growth and food intake among the 4 groups. The results showed that MTBE significantly increased the weights of liver and kidneys, but the levels of serum enzymes and proteins were not greatly changed. No apparent pathological changes in the main organs (liver, kidneys, testes, and lungs) were found by light microscopy, but electron microscopy analysis showed significant changes in liver cells of all treatment groups, including cell nuclear condensation, fat drops and lysosomes in cells, and smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) dispersion. The effects on the health of 96 MTBE occupationally exposed workers and 102 controls were also investigated by a questionnaire, and we found that workers who reported health complaints in MTBE exposed group (62 cases, 64.6%) were significantly more numerous (P<.001) than those in the control group (16 cases, 16.7%), and the OR value was 9.80 (95% C.I. is 4.74- 20.53). The most frequently reported symptoms in the exposed group were eye irritation (19.8%), dizziness (18.8%), burning sensation in the nose or throat (17.7%), insomnia (13.5%), nausea or vomiting (13.5%), headache (12.5%), fatigue (12.5%), poor memory (12,5%), irritability (6.3%) and skin irritation or redness (5.2%). The data suggested that MTBE may be toxic to male SD rats at high doses, and MTBE may have harmful effects on exposed workers.
Author Keywords: Health effects; Methyl Tertiary Butyl Ether; SD rats; Subchronic; Workers

Authors: Ziman Stephen D.
Title: Appropriate uses of air quality models for developing regional ozone plans and related planning issues: Issues and problems for both the 1-hour and 8-hour U.S. ozone standards as they affect petroleum production areas
Affiliations: Chevron Research and Technology Co, Richmond, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ziman, Stephen D., Chevron Research and Technology Co, Richmond, United States
Abstract: The issues associated with the adoption of a new U.S. National Ambient Air Quality Standard for ozone are described. The standard is set at 80 parts per billion (ppb) averaged over 8 hours. The new standard has also resulted in regulatory changes in the planning process that develops control measures to reduce ozone precursor emissions and demonstrates attainment of the standard in a specified time frame. The planning process would utilize both modeling information to develop a plan, along with an iterative reviews of the modeling and analysis of changes in ozone over 5 to 6 years after enactment of the plan to determine if the original strategy was achieved.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Mathematical models; Oil well production; Ozone; Petroleum prospecting; Regional planning; Standards; Ozone standards; Air pollution control

Authors: Zimmermann P.A.
Title: A hydroclimatic approach to assessing wildfire risk in Pennsylvania
Authors with affiliations: Zimmermann, P.A.
Abstract: A climate-based approach is employed to assess wildfire risk in a two-county region in Pennsylvania. A generalized ground cover is applied to Schuylkill and Carbon counties and the duff moisture content within it is computed using a method based on the Thornthwaite-Mather water budget. Water budget computations are performed for Tamaqua, PA, and are used to investigate the feasibility of using a single station for the study area. Daily duff moisture data are then compared with daily fire to examine the relationships between wildfire occurrence and the moisture state of the duff. This analysis is conducted for the years 1981 to 1984 and 1988 to 1991. Results show that drier duff conditions are associated with increased numbers of mean fires per day, increased fire-day ratios, and greater numbers of fires per fire day. These relationships are evident when the study period is examined as a whole. Deviations from these established relationships are seen when individual study years are analyzed. This is likely due to the anthropogenic nature of wildfires in Pennsylvania. Overall, the Thornthwaite-Mather water budget does designate dry and possibly dangerous conditions quite satisfactorily.
Index Keywords: climate effect; risk assessment; water budget; wildfire; United States

Authors: Zingale N.
Title: Study shows that market forces improve the environment
Affiliations: Affinity Environmental Group, Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Zingale, N., Affinity Environmental Group, Inc.
Abstract: Title IV of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 (the acid rain title) established goals to reduce annual emissions of sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) and to place a national cap on sulfur dioxide emissions beginning in the year 2000. Under the program, each affected utility received its allocation of allowances every year. The results of the SO2 emission- trading program have been successful and are expected to have continued success through 2005. According to a study completed by Dallas Burtraw, Resources for the Future and Erin Mansur, University of California Energy Institute, the proponents of the market based pollution reduction approach are winning. Burtraw and Mansur primarily studied the environmental effects of SO2 trading and banking. Through the use of emission models and expected outcomes, they concluded that although emission increases can be expected in the Ohio Valley, they do not do so in all states.

Authors: Zu Y., Fan F.-R.F., Bard A.J.
Title: Inverted region electron transfer demonstrated by electrogenerated chemiluminescence at the liquid/liquid interface
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zu, Y., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Fan, F.-R.F., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Bard, A.J., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: We describe several transinterface electron-transfer processes occurring at the benzonitrile (PhCN)/water interface that produce excited states. When an electrode was moved very close to the interface or even through the interface to produce an electrode/thin layer organic phase/aqueous solution configuration, the electro-generated radical species formed in the PhCN phase (C12-Ru(bpy)33+, DPA+, or TH+) diffused to the liquid/ liquid interface to react with (oxidize) a coreactant (C2O42-) soluble only in the aqueous solution, leading to the formation of a strongly reducing radical species (CO2•-). The electron transfer from CO2•- in the aqueous solution to the oxidized species in the organic phase across the liquid/liquid interface produced an electronically excited state which then emitted light. The appearance of an ECL signal in these systems supports the suggestion of Marcus inverted region behavior in very exothermic heterogeneous electron-transfer reactions at the liquid/ liquid interface. © 1999 American Chemical Society.

Authors: Zweiri Y.H., Whidborne J.F., Seneviratne L.D.
Title: Dynamic simulation of a single-cylinder diesel engine including dynamometer modelling and friction
Source title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, King's College, London, United Kingdom; Division of Engineering, King's College London, Strand, London WC2R 2LS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Zweiri, Y.H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, King's College, London, United Kingdom, Division of Engineering, King's College London, Strand, London WC2R 2LS, United Kingdom; Whidborne, J.F., Department of Mechanical Engineering, King's College, London, United Kingdom; Seneviratne, L.D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, King's College, London, United Kingdom, Division of Engineering, King's College London, Strand, London WC2R 2LS, United Kingdom
Abstract: The recent drive to reduce emissions and improve efficiency means that there is a real need for improved models for the simulation of direct-injection diesel engines. With a view to improving the transient fuel control, a model of the non-linear transient dynamics of a generic direct-injection single-cylinder diesel engine is developed in order to predict the instantaneous engine speed and torque. The instantaneous crankshaft speed is determined from the solution of the engine-external load dynamics equation, where the engine torque is tracked on a crank angle basis. The model is based on an analysis of all the major forces internal to the engine and dynamometer. The friction components of the piston assembly, the bearings, the valve train, the pumping and the pumps are also included. The model is implemented in MATLAB/SIMULINK, and simulation results of both transient and steady state dynamics are presented. The simulation results of the instantaneous engine speed are compared with measured data, and it is seen that there is excellent agreement between them. © IMechE 1999.
Author Keywords: Diesel engine; Dynamic modelling; Engine friction; Simulation; Transient response

Authors: Zylicz T.
Title: Environmental policy in economies in transition
Source title: Scandinavian Journal of Work, Environment and Health
Affiliations: Warsaw Ecological Economics Center, Warsaw University, Warsaw, Poland; Warsaw Ecological Economics Center, Warsaw University, 44 - 50 Dluga Street, 00 - 241 Warsaw, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Zylicz, T., Warsaw Ecological Economics Center, Warsaw University, Warsaw, Poland, Warsaw Ecological Economics Center, Warsaw University, 44 - 50 Dluga Street, 00 - 241 Warsaw, Poland
Abstract: Considerable improvement in environmental pollution has been achieved, primarily due to targeted environmental policies rather than general economic developments. Some countries in central and eastern Europe have managed to reduce emissions even after the gross domestic product once again began to increase. Everywhere in the region, however, the cost-effectiveness of environmental spending is questionable. Most countries have established systems of earmarked resource and pollution taxes, which provide a sizable share in financing environmental investment. With stationary sources of pollution brought under increasingly effective control, the environmental problems in central and eastern Europe, and eventually in the newly independent states, will start to resemble those of developed market economies. As more activities become affected by environmental protection measures, cost-effectiveness considerations deserve increased attention.
Author Keywords: Cost-effectiveness; Environmental pollution; Policy reform
Index Keywords: environmental policy; pollution control; transitional economy; conference paper; cost effectiveness analysis; Eastern Europe; economic aspect; economic development; environmental protection; policy; pollution; priority journal; Cost-Benefit Analysis; Environmental Pollution; Europe; Humans; International Cooperation; Public Policy

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of State Implementation Plans: Alaska
Abstract: EPA is approving various revisions to the CO Alaska SIP effective on 2/28/2000. Submitted in three different packages to EPA in 2/6/97, 6/1/98, and 9/10/98, SIP revisions cover the Transportation Conformity Rule, Emissions Inspection and Maintenance (I/M) requirements for Motor Vehicles, and Fuel Requirements for Motor Vehicles. Highlights include changing the I/M program schedule from annual to biennial; replacing the CO contingency measures for Anchorage; and streamlining and updating several portions of the Alaska Air Quality Control Plan for more efficient reading and organization.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plan for Louisiana: Transportation conformity rule
Abstract: EPA is approving a revision to the Louisiana SIP containing the transportation conformity rule, allowing the State to implement the Federal transportation conformity requirements at the State level. The conformity rules ensure that in air quality nonattainment or maintenance areas, projected emissions (including CO, NO2, O3, SO2, Pb, and particulate matter) from transportation plans and projects are within the motor vehicle emissions ceiling in the SIP. Effective on 2/28/2000, EPA's approval streamlines the conformity process and permits direct consultation among agencies at the local levels.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Control of emissions of air pollution from new marine compression-ignition engines at or above 37 kW
Abstract: EPA is establishing an emission control program for new marine diesel engines rated ≥ 37 kw effective on 1/28/2000. The affected engines are utilized for propulsion and auxiliary purposes in a wide range of marine applications. The standards for these engines will require significant reductions in NOx and particulate matter emissions to correspond with the next round of emission standards for comparable land-based engines. When combined with other mobile source emission control programs, the new program will help provide long-term improvements in air quality in several port cities and other coastal areas. These emission standards give much-needed support to state facing ozone and particulate air quality problems that can cause various health effects for their residents, particularly in terms of respiratory impairment and related illnesses.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Delaware, Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Virginia; Approval of National Low Emission Vehicle programs
Abstract: EPA approves the SIP revisions submitted by the Commonwealths of Pennsylvania and Virginia, and the States of Maryland and Delaware, formalizing each state's commitment to accept sales of motor vehicles that comply with the requirements of the National Low Emission Vehicle (National LEV) program, a voluntary nationwide clean car program designed to reduce ground level ozone (smog) and other air pollution emitted from newly manufactured motor vehicles. In this direct final rule taking effect 2/28/2000, EPA approves the Delaware low emission rule submitted on 9/1/99 into the Delaware SIP; the Maryland low emission vehicle rule submitted on 3/3/99 (as amended on 3/24/99) into the Maryland SIP; the Pennsylvania's National LEV rule submitted on 1/8/99 into the Pennsylvania SIP; and Virginia's low emission vehicle rule submitted on 5/27/99 into the Virginia SIP. The National LEV regulations allow auto manufacturers to commit to meet tailpipe standards for cars and light-duty trucks that are more stringent than EPA could otherwise mandate under the authority of the Clean Air Act. These regulations provided that the program would take effect only with the participation of Northeast states and auto manufacturers.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; State of Missouri
Abstract: EPA approves certain portions of the SIP revisions submitted by the state of Missouri and as revisions to the part 70 (operating permits) program (″Submission of Emission Data, Emission Fees and Process Information″) in a direct final rule taking effect 2/22/2000. The revisions established emission and service fees for 1997 and 1998 and clarify language on reporting requirements, emission calculations and verification.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; California State Implementation Plan Revision, South Coast Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA has taken direct final action on revisions to the California SIP concerning rule rescissions from the South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD). The action rescinds the rules from the federally approved SIP to update and clarify the SIP in accordance with the 1990 Clean Air Act requirements. The rule rescissions are obsolete rules that have been suspended or removed from SCAQMD regulations, and include concerns on the determination of VOC in organic materials, power plants, air pollution control, and fuel burning equipment. The rule is effective 2/22/2000 unless the EPA receives written objections by 1/21/2000.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; Texas; Control of Air Pollution from Volatile Organic Compounds, Miscellaneous Industrial Sources, cutback asphalt
Abstract: EPA has taken direct final action on revisions to the Texas SIP concerning the control of air pollution from VOC, miscellaneous industrial sources, particularly, asphaltic operations in Nueces County and the ozone nonattainment areas. The revisions were approved to regulate VOC emissions in accordance with Clean Air Act requirements. The VOC volume on cutback use in Nueces County will be limited from 8 to 7%, making the county more consistent with the volume limitation for cutback use in the ozone nonattainment areas. The rule will also allow the use of alternative asphalt mixes with equal or less VOC emissions and will offer more operational flexibility for a source to meet market demands. The rule is effective 2/22/2000 unless the agency receives adverse comment by 1/21/2000.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; State of New Mexico; approval of revised maintenance plan for Albuquerque/Bernalillo County; Albuquerque/Bernalillo County, New Mexico; carbon monoxide
Abstract: The EPA is approving, by direct final action, a revision to the Albuquerque/Bernalillo County CO SIP concerning changes and adjustments to three main categories of emissions in the maintenance plan, which the Governor of New Mexico requested on 2/4/99. The changes concern the baseline emission inventory, approval of a new Motor Vehicle Emissions Budget, and amendments to budget projections in the CO maintenance plan. The CAAA mandates that CO areas redesignated to attainment must adopt plans that will keep air pollution levels below the health-based standard, particularly during times of growth. Albuquerque is resetting budget levels for mobile, point source, and area source emissions. However, it is not increasing the overall emissions allowed in the basin. Contingency measures include increasing the frequency of vehicle inspection and maintenance program and increasing the oxygenate content in gasoline sold during winter. The rule is effective 2/18/2000 unless the EPA receives written objections by 1/19/2000.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; California State Implementation Plan revision, Ventura County Air Pollution Control District, Project XL site-specific rulemaking for Imation Corp. Camarillo Plant
Abstract: EPA has finalized the approval of revisions to the SIP proposed on 9/18/99 concerning Rule 37 ″Project XL″ from the Ventura County Air Pollution district. The intended effect of approving this rule is to regulate VOC emissions in accordance with the requirements of the CAAA and to facilitate implementation of the XL Project at Imation Corp. in Camarillo, CA. Such implementation will result in superior environmental performance and provide Imation with greater operational flexibility. This action is effective on 1/12/2000.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Environmental update: EPA moves to strengthen urban air pollution plans in major urban areas
Abstract: EPA is taking action to strengthen smog-reduction plans in nine major urban areas: Atlanta, Baltimore, Chicago, Greater Connecticut (Hartford), Houston, Milwaukee, New York City, Philadelphia, and Washington, D.C. The initial EPA review involved air quality plans for 10 areas covering 13 states and the District of Columbia. EPA decided that every plan, except that for western Massachusetts, requires further work to protect public health and the environment. Significant plan revisions for the Houston-Galveston area currently under expedited review were submitted to EPA on 11/15/99. According to the CAAA, the covered areas should develop plans for providing cleaner air to their constituents. Except for western Massachusetts, these areas will have to update their transportation and air quality planning for compliance. The plans are especially important in urban areas with growing threats to air quality from smog-producing traffic congestion and other sources.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Coastal engineering and marina developments. Proceedings of the 4th international conference on computer modellings of
Source title: Coastal engineering and marina developments.Proceedings of the 4th international conference on computer modelling of seas and coastal regions. Lemnos, May 1999.
Abstract: This volume contains the Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Computer Modelling of Seas and Coastal Regions, which took place on the island of Lemnos, Greece in May 1999, under the joint organisation of the Wessex Institute of Technology, UK and the Division of Hydraulics and Environmental Engineering of the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece. Problems such as pollution and general degradation of coastal areas have become a major international concern and the related environmental problems need further study to design remedial actions. Moreover the design and construction of developments necessary for navigation such as harbours and marinas requires an accurate knowledge of the sea climate, especially in cases of extreme conditions. Computer models are an efficient tool to analyse the coastal systems, in combination with remote sensing and experimental sampling techniques. The conference attracted contributions from many different countries, covering a multitude of topics and techniques in a wide variety of areas such as estuarine problems, shallow water models, siltation and dredging, tidal simulation, wave studies, pollution studies, coastal erosion and marina developments. This volume also contains the Proceedings of the International Seminar on the planning, design and operation of marinas, held to coincide with the Coastal Engineering Conference.
Index Keywords: coastal engineering; marina; coastal development; coastal engineering; conference proceedings; marina

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Fuels and engines need to be developed together
Abstract: A discussion covers the need for automotive and oil industries to work together to develop engine/vehicle technology and fuel quality as a common technical system to meet stringent future emissions levels; the principles and issues which are key to the development of fuel specifications, including vehicle emissions reduction, customer acceptance (e.g. driveability performance), CO2, fuel consumption, and durability; the importance of understanding the local causes of the air quality problem; and economical use of fuel parameters to control vehicle performance or emissions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: France: BP started cleanerfuels initiative in Paris
Abstract: In view of a global program to produce a range of cleaner fuels that maximize performance while minimizing exhaust emissions, BP, the first oil company in France, offers the new Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) that reduces sulfur emissions by 90% on all diesel vehicles without any detrimental effect on performance, and will be offered at no extra cost to motorists. ULSD, which already anticipates the 2005 EU sulfur specifications and is available in the Paris region, also significantly reduces other emissions and enables new particulate reduction technology to be fitted on buses and other transport vehicles. BP has also chosen to develop, along with Butagaz, one of the largest Autogas (LPG) networks in this region. Rodney Chase, Deputy Group Chief Executive of BP Amoco, stated that Paris was one of the very first cities chosen by BP Amoco to introduce cleaner fuels, as LPG is known as a clean fuel with considerably lower emissions and also with the benefit of tax incentives.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Two-stroke outboards under threat
Abstract: Discusses the environmental pressures and regulations facing small marine outboard engines, and the new technologies being developed to address these. The effect of these pressures on market and technological trends in USA and Europe are also considered. The use of outboard engines on inland waterways may be limited by emissions restrictions and political and public opinion. Pollution can be reduced by either reducing emissions or by making substances, such as lubricants, biodegradable. Direct-injection two-stroke technology has reduced hydrocarbon emissions significantly.
Author Keywords: Emission; Emission control; Engine; Environmental impact; Environmental issue; Marine engine; Marine pollution
Index Keywords: Europe; internal combustion engine; lubricant; pollution control; United States; emission; environmental impact; marine engine; emission control; engine; environmental issue; marine pollution

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Industry briefs: Environment - Alberta
Abstract: Alberta set up an agency to promote the reduction of greenhouse gases in the province that produces 80% of Canada's oil and gas, and most of its emissions of greenhouse gases. With funding of $(Can)2 million/yr, Climate Change Central aims to support business partnerships in projects that advance the emission-reducing cause. According to the Pembina Institute, an Alberta environmental research group, the government has underestimated the scope of the problem and that funding of $30-50 million/yr is required for an effective program.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: UPFront: Emissions control: CO2 sequestration, offset projects grow
Abstract: The DOE released in September 1999 a new solicitation offering ≤ $18-million to develop concepts that can capture and sequester CO2 and other greenhouse gases. A 1997 state law requires that new fossil fuel power plants generate 17% fewer carbon emissions than is achievable with the best available control technology by putting in a more efficient plant, using a cogeneration cycle, or creating carbon offsets. PacifiCorp, Portland, OR, is spending $500,000 to help provide China, India, and Sri Lanka with solar electricity for the next 30 years, as part of its $5.5-million carbon-mitigation program for the new 500-Mw Klamath Cogeneration Project being developed in Oregon. Other projects in the Klamath's plant include tree planting or under-producing lands in Oregon, converting waste methane to electricity, expanding the Klamath Falls geothermal district heating system, and providing $1.3 million to the Oregon Climate Trust for the state's CO2 offset programs.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: World News: BP Amoco cuts emissions
Abstract: BP Amoco plans to introduce lower-sulfur gasoline in Chicago, IL, a move that would result in reduced emissions equivalent to 70,500 less cars each day on the city's roads. The fuels will be available by the spring of 2001, way ahead of the EPA 2004 deadline for proposed sulfur requirements. BP will also spend > $100 million over the next two years to modify its refining and related operations in an effort to provide environmentally friendly oil, gas, petrochemicals, and solar power.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: DOE urges extension for refiners under sulfur proposal
Abstract: In a letter to the EPA, a DOE official criticized a proposed rule to reduce gasoline sulfur levels, saying the rule would economically disrupt the refining industry and raise gasoline prices. The concerns in the letter are strikingly similar to those voiced by the industry. The letter (7/31) urged the EPA to extend the compliance deadline for refiners to 2007 from EPA's proposed 2004-2007 time frame. It was also recomended that the sulfur requirement be raised from EPA's proposed 30 ppm to a declining standard of 250 ppm in 2004, 175 ppm in 2005, 100 ppm in 2006, and finally 30 ppm in 2007. EPA's proposal would also require automakers to produce passenger and sport utility vehicles that emit low levels of NOx when run with the new fuel. Once in place, NOx emissions would drop by 800,000 tons/yr by 2007; without the sulfur reductions, vehicle emissions will contribute 30-40% of national NOx and VOC emissions in certain cities by 2020, according to the EPA.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Controls and sensors
Abstract: A discussion on two of the newer developments in controls and sensors, i.e., oscillating combustion and flame signature analysis (FSA) covers the principle of combustion and its basic components (time, temperature, and turbulence); functions of control valves, air/fuel ratio controls, pressure controls, complete combustion and supervising control, and process control optimization; qualification of CeramPhysics, Inc's oscillation combustion valve, a solid-state proportioning valve with a fast response that is noise free and can operate for long periods of time, in field tests on an oxy-gas-fired rotary cast iron melter and on an air-gas-fired ladle preheater; and the Gas Research Institute's development program in FSA to provide real-time combustion control, aiding the natural gas industry in improving the way to determine air/gas ratio, NOx production, and the onset of soot formation, and in improving overall performance due to higher efficiency, improved productivity, reduced NOx emissions, and enhanced reliability and safety by incorporating a performance margin into the control system to accommodate variations in load, atmospheric conditions, and application, and dynamic control of the burner's fuel/air ratio under various operating and environmental conditions to improve efficiency and emissions.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Understanding global water cycle is key to managing climate change, NRC reports
Abstract: The U.S. climate change program should not overlook the importance of water cycle research for local water managers shouldered with decision making today for future potential crises stemming from climate change, notes the National Research Council's Committee on Hydrologic Science. These decision makers' informational needs should help guide the evolution of new initiatives within the nation's global climate research program, the committee concludes.
Index Keywords: climate; decision making; environmental management; periodicity; short survey; water management

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Leaking USTs reported as major source of groundwater contamination
Abstract: EPA Blue Ribbon Panel, appointed late 1998 to study problems with the nation's air and water quality, determined that leaking UST for gasoline remains the primary source of groundwater contamination. The panel comprised of experts on air and water quality and representatives of the oil, ethanol, and MTBE industries, was assembled after reports of MTBE detection in drinking water supplies in California, Maine, and elsewhere. The reforms are designed to ensure that water supplies are better protected while maintaining reductions in air pollution that have resulted from the Federal Reformulated Gasoline (RFG) Program. The panel recommended the following actions, e.g., implement a comprehensive set of improvements to the nation's water protection programs, including more than 20 specific actions to enhance UST, safe drinking water, and private well protection programs; provide clear federal and state authority to regulate and/or eliminate the use of MTBE and other gasoline additives that threaten drinking water supplies; remove the current Clean Air Act requirement that 2 wt % RFG consist of oxygen so adequate fuel supplies can be blended in a cost-effective manner. The panel arrived at these recommendations after a 6-mo investigation. Among its findings were RFG has provided substantial reductions in the emissions of air pollutants from motor vehicles; 5-10% of drinking water supplies in RFG areas are showing detectable amounts of MTBE.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of Maryland; enhanced inspection and maintenance program
Abstract: EPA is converting its conditional approval of the State of Maryland's SIP revision for an enhanced vehicle inspection and maintenance (I/M) program, which was granted on 7/31/97 (61 FR 40938), to a full approval. In Maryland, the I/M program is known as the vehicle emissions inspection program. In the conditional approval, the agency imposed 15 conditions for full approval, which the state has met. Residents of Maryland and neighboring states will significantly benefit from the program, which is designed to keep vehicles maintained and operating within pollution control standards. Subjects included in 40 CFR Part 52 are environmental protection, air pollution control, hydrocarbons, incorporation by reference, ozone, and intergovernmental relations. The rule is effective on 12/28/99, unless EPA receives adverse written comment by 11/29/99.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: EPA puts MTBE water degradation before air quality benefits
Abstract: Five years after the federal reformulated gasoline program went into effect, EPA Administrator Carol Browner announced that the agency would work with Congress to reduce the use of MTBE in the national fuel supply. The announcement follows a decision by California Governor Gray Davis to ban MTBE fuel in his state and a movement by several New England states to drop the RFG program because of drinking water pollution. It came just before EPA's Blue Ribbon Panel of Oxygenates in Gasoline released a summary of its 6-mo investigation into MTBE, which noted that the RFG program has made considerable progress in reduce CO emissions. However, the panel advocated an MTBE phase-down over the next 4 yr because it was quickly degrading the quality of drinking water in wells across the nation. Since the late 1960s, the oil industry has been using MTBE in much lower levels as a replacement for lead. Like other fuels, MTBE leaks into groundwater from UST and onto reservoir surface water from speedboats. The possibility for congressional debate over lifting the RFG requirement from the Clean Air Act is promising.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of state air quality plans for designated facilities and pollutants; Delaware; control of emissions from existing municipal solid waste landfills
Abstract: EPA has issued a direct final rule approving the MSW landfill 111(d) plan submitted by the Delaware Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control on 4/23/98. The plan satisfies CAA requirements by establishing emission limits for existing MSW landfills and providing for the implementation and enforcement of those limits. The EPA action takes effect on 11/16/99. The pollutants this action will control include CO2, methane, and NMOC ( nonmethane organic compounds). NMOC includes vinyl chloride, toluene, and benzene among > 100 different compounds. Also discussed are the federal requirements that the Delaware 111(d) plan must meet for approval; requirements that affected MSW landfill owners/operators must meet; provisions of the EPA final rule; administrative requirements; and amendments to 40 CFR Part 62.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Notice of direct final rule revisions to emissions budgets set forth in EPA's finding of significant contribution and rulemaking for purposes of reducing regional transport of ozone for the states of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island
Abstract: EPA takes direct final action to redistribute the combined electric generating stationary source (EGU) portion of the NOx emission reduction requirements among the states of Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Rhode Island. These three states approached the EPA with concerns about the distribution of the emission reduction requirements to them, following EPA's final action on 10/27/98. This action requires 22 states and the District of Columbia to submit SIP revisions to prohibit specified amounts of emissions of NOx to reduce NOx and ozone transport across state boundaries in eastern USA. This action is known as the NOx SIP Call. They were concerned that the specific emission reductions that EPA required from each of them were inconsistent with the emissions that those states were required to reduce in connection with an existing multi-state effort to reduce NOx and ozone transport across state boundaries in northeastern USA. Subsequent to the signing of a memorandum of understanding (MOU) by EPA and the three states in February 1999 which required EPA to redistribute the NOx emission reduction requirements among the three states, EPA took a final action changing the EGU portion of the budget for the three states in a Technical Amendment to the NOx SIP Call published on 5/14/99. The final redistribution is slightly different than the redistribution as stated in the MOU to reflect the 5/14/99 changes to the budgets. This action is effective on 11/1/99.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Kentucky: Approval of revisions to the Louisville State Implementation Plan
Abstract: The EPA has made a direct final rule approving the Air Pollution Control District of Jefferson County portion of the SIP filed by the Commonwealth of Kentucky through the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Cabinet on 11/12/93 and revised on 4/5/94 and 6/30/97. The SIP covers the 15% Rate-of-Progress Plan for the moderate ozone non-attainment area of Louisville, KY. The submission satisfied the 15% reduction in VOC emissions required by Section 182(b)(1)(A) of the CAAA. The EPA has expressed its approval of the plan, including the individual measures that meet the 15% VOC reduction and the Jefferson County 1990 Base Year Emissions Inventory, which was filed by Kentucky in fulfillment of CAA Section 182(b) requirements. The direct final rule will take effect on 11/12/99 without further notice, unless adverse comment is received by the EPA by 10/13/99. Supplementary information is provided.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; California State Implementation Plan revision, Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District and Tehama County Air Pollution Control District
Abstract: The EPA is giving its final approval to the changes recommended for the California SIP concerning the recision of rules for the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District (MDAQMD) and Tehama County Air Pollution control District (TCAPCD). The MDAQMD rules are targeted at emissions from orchard heaters while the rules for TCAPCD are concerned with fuel burning equipment. The revisions will bring the two SIPs in harmony with the requirements of the Clean Air Act (CAA). EPA has examined the submitted rule recisions and has found that they are consistent with the CAA, EPA regulations and EPA policy. The final rule will take effect on 10/13/99. Supplementation information regarding applicability, background, response to public comments, EPA evaluation and final action, and administrative requirements are discussed.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Finding of failure to submit a required state implementation plan for carbon monoxide; Nevada-Las Vegas Valley
Abstract: EPA takes final action effective 8/31/99 after finding that Nevada failed to meet the 5/3/99 deadline for submission of a CO nonattainment area SIP for the Las Vegas Valley under the Clean Air Act (CAA). This action, consistent with the CAA mechanism for assuring SIP submissions, triggers the 18-mo time clock for mandatory application of sanctions and 2-yr time clock for a federal implementation plan (FIP) under CAA section 110(c). If Nevada will not have made the required complete submittal of a SIP revision addressing the serious area CO requirements of the CAA by 3/2/01, the offset sanction in CAA section 179(b) will be applied in the affected area. If the State has still not made a complete submission by 8/31/01, the highway funding sanction will apply in the affected area, according to 40 CFR 52.31 and EPA must also promulgate a FIP under CAA.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of state plans for designated facilities and pollutants; Maryland; control of emissions from existing municipal solid waste landfills
Abstract: The EPA approved the MSW landfill 111(d) plan, designed to fulfill requirements of the Clean Air Act, submitted by the Air and Radiation Management Administration, Maryland Department of the Environment on 3/23/99. The Maryland plan, creating emission limits for existing MSW landfills and providing for the execution and enforcement of those limits, focuses on the control of nonmethane organic compound emissions from MSW landfills. It applies to all existing MSW landfills in Maryland for which construction, reconstruction, or modification was commenced before 5/30/91, and that accepted waste at any time since 11/08/87, or that have additional capacity available for future waste deposition, as described in 40 CFR part 60, subpart Cc. The final rule is effective 11/08/99, unless adverse or critical comments are received through 10/08/99.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; Massachusetts; Reasonably available control technology for major stationary sources of nitrogen oxides and nitrogen oxide requirements at municipal waste combustors
Abstract: EPA approves SIP revisions submitted by Massachusetts in response to the Clean Air Act (CAA) requirement that all stationary sources with the potential to emit 50 tons or more/yr of NOx must install and operate RACT. EPA also approves facility-specific NOx RACT emission control plans (ECP) for Specialty Minerals, Inc in Adams, Monsanto Co's Indian Orchard facility in Springfield, Medusa Minerals Co (formerly Lee Lime) in Lee, and Turners Falls LP/Indeck Energy Services Turners Falls, Inc in Montague (Turners Falls). Massachusetts' NOx RACT regulation and facility-specific RACT determinations require certain stationary sources, such as power plants and factories with boilers, to limit their daily, or in some cases monthly, airborne emissions of NOx. EPA considers an aggregate reduction in NOx of 30-50% from a 1990 baseline emission level to be RACT. Massachusetts has also requested SIP approval of NOx emission limits, monitoring, record keeping, and reporting requirements for municipal waste combustors that were promulgated under Massachusetts' regulation 310 CMR 7.08(2), Municipal Waste Combustors. The state has requested that EPA approve the NOx-related requirements of 310 CMR 7.08(2) into the SIP to reduce ozone pursuant to section 110, Implementation Plans, of the CAA as well. This action takes effect on 11/1/99.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of state implementation plans: Alaska
Abstract: EPA is approving various amendments to Alaska's CO Air Quality Control Plan, including revisions to Air Quality Control Regulations, Emissions Inspection and Maintenance (I/M) Requirements for Motor Vehicles, and Fuel Requirements for Motor Vehicles. The amendments are contained in three separate submittals to EPA, dated 2/6/97, 6/1/98, and 9/10/98. EPA approves all changes to I/M regulations submitted by the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation which include changing the program schedule for cars subject to I/M from annual to biennial, replacing the CO contingency measures for Anchorage, updating Alaska's General and Transportation conformity programs, and streamlining several portions of the Alaska Air Quality Control Plan for more efficient reading and organization. This final rule is effective on 11/1/99 and subject to adverse comment by 10/1/99.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Decreasing acid rain increases global warming
Abstract: Results of studies by scientists at the University of Illinois suggest that controlling future emissions of SO2 to reduce acid rain may exacerbate the global warming problem. Professor Michael Schlesinger and his colleagues found that decreasing SO2 emissions in global-mean surface temperature models resulted in considerable regional warming in certain parts of Europe, North America, Siberia, and the North Atlantic. The studies were based on the provisional greenhouse gas and SO2 emissions developed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) as part of a special report entitled 'Emissions Scenarios'.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Product news: New radar based level gauge introduced by Saab Tank Control
Abstract: Singapore-based Atlas Copco Pte will expand its portable oil free air compressor rental fleet in response to the demand of the region's manufacturing, oil, chemical and processing industries for 100% oil fee operation. The new PTS960 compressor is fully automatic, rated to provide an actual free air delivery of 45 cu m/min (1600 cu ft/min) and features variable pressure of 3-10.5 bar. It complies with current emissions regulations and is silenced to meet 76 dB. The PTMS1200 compressor is rated 10.5 bar to provide free air delivery of 34 cu m/min (1200 cu ft/min).

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Clear path for smog program
Abstract: The National Research Council of Canada (NRC), Ottawa, has licensed an air quality modeling technology from its Institute for Chemical Process and Environmental Technology to Rowan Williams Davies & Irwin, Inc (RWDI), Guelph, Ontario. RWDI will correlate and model the amounts of emissions and meteorological data needed to determine the chemical and physical interactions that produce smog using the modeling software. NRC will continue to work with RWDI and other companies to advance and integrate aerosol chemistry research into the modeling package. Photochemical modeling is an advanced technique combining air emissions data with topography and meteorology to produce a 3D animated model of the chemical reactions leading to ozone. It can also be used to forecast the positive effects of reductions in emission levels on ozone formation. The modeling system can test different scenarios to predict the effect on air quality caused by introducing pollution control measures, such as replacing gasoline-powered vehicles with those fueled by natural gas, or expanding an urban rapid transit system.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Clean Air Act approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plan revision for North Dakota; revisions to the air pollution control rules; delegation of authority for new source performance standards
Abstract: Revisions to the SIP, submitted by the North Dakota Governor, that affect air pollution controls rules on general provisions, the State SO2 ambient air quality standard, emissions of particulate matter and organic compounds, and permits to construct, were approved by the EPA and will be effective on 11/1/99. Revisions to the Title V operating permit program, a delegation request for emission standards for hazardous air pollutants for source categories, and the State's plan for hospital, medical, and infectious waste incinerations will be handled by EPA individually. Finally, a notice being provided by EPA stated that North Dakota was delegated authority as of 5/7/99 to implement and enforce the New Source Performance Standards in 40 CFR part 60 from 11/1/97.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; California State Implementation Plan revision, South Coast Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is taking a direct final action on a revision to the California SIP regarding a rule from the SCAQMD, under provisions of the CAAA on the EPA action on SIP submittals, SIPs for national primary and secondary ambient air quality standards and plan requirements for nonattainment areas. The approval action, which will incorporate the rule into the federally approved SIP, has the intended effect of regulating VOC emissions according to the requirements of CAAA. The revised rule controls VOC emissions from commercial and industrial adhesive, sealant, and primer applications and will be effective on 11/1/99.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of State Implementation Plans; California
Abstract: EPA approves the State of California's SIP revision signifying that its Low Emission Vehicle (LEV) program can take the place of the Clean Air Act Clean Fuel Fleet (CAA CFF) vehicle program. The approval, taking effect on 9/27/99, is based on the emission benefits analysis conducted by CARB demonstrating that the LEV program offers long-term reduction in ozone and toxic air contaminants exceeding those of the CAA CFF program. Estimated emission benefits showed that implementation of LEV program will reduce 46.2 tons/day of reactive organic gas (ROG), 223.2 tons/day of NOx and 50.1 tons/day of CO in 2000 over that of the CAA CFF program that will reduce ROG, NOx and CO emissions by 2.2, 5.0 and 6.0 tons/day, respectively. CARB stated that the reduction of ROG entails a concurrent reduction of its benzene, formaldehyde and 1,3-butadiene contents, which according to an EPA study on motor vehicle related toxic air contaminants pose the greatest risk to human health or about which significant uncertainties remain.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of air quality implementation plans; State of Colorado; Colorado Springs carbon monoxide redesignation to attainment, designation of areas for air quality planning purposes, and approval of a related revision
Abstract: EPA has approved the request by the Governor of Colorado to redesignate the Colorado Springs area from ″moderate″ CO nonattainment to attainment for the CO NAAQS. The agency has also approved the maintenance plan designed to keep the area in attainment for CO for the next 11 years, and the revisions to Colorado's Regulation No. 13 for the implementation of the wintertime ″Oxygenated Fuels Program″ submitted by the Governor. This action is effective on 10/25/99 subject to adverse comments by 9/24/99. The Colorado Springs area has met the five criteria for redesignation: attainment of the CO NAAQS; compliance with all applicable requirements under Section 110 and Part D of the Clean Air Act (CAA); a fully approved SIP under Section 110(k) of the CAA; improvement in air quality is due to permanent and enforceable emissions reductions; and a fully approved maintenance plan under CAA Section 175A. Further changes to Regulation No. 13 sought by the state include shortening of the oxygenated fuels season by one week and reducing the minimum oxygen content in fuels for the first and last weeks of the program.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of implementation plans; California State Implementation Plan Revision; South Coast Air Quality Management District; Ventura County Air Pollution Control District; Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District
Abstract: EPA is taking final action on revisions to the California SIP concerning rules from the SCAQMD, VCAPCD, and MDAQMD. The approval action will integrate two rules into the federally approved SIP and remove two rules from it. Approving the rules will regulate VOC emissions based on requirements of the 1990 Clean Air Act. The two rules control VOC emissions from storage tank cleaning and degassing operations, and from components at crude oil and natural gas production and processing facilities. The two rules to be removed control VOC emissions from compressors, pumps, and relief valves. Supplementary information pertaining to the rules is presented, which will be effective on 10/18/99 unless the EPA receives adverse comments by 9/20/99.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Approval and promulgation of Air Quality Implementation Plan; Connecticut; Approval of National Low Emission Vehicle Program
Abstract: EPA has issued a direct final rule approving SIP revisions submitted by Connecticut on 2/7/96 and 2/18/99 expressing the State's commitment to comply with the National LEV Program requirements as a compliance option for new motor vehicles sold in the State, which had also adopted the California LEV program. Automakers have agreed to sell cleaner vehicles meeting the National LEV standards throughout Connecticut and California for the duration of their commitments to the National LEV Program. The SIP revision is part of the agreement between States and automobile manufacturers to ensure the continuation of the National LEV Program to produce clean cars throughout most of the country, starting with 1999 model year vehicles in Northeastern States and extending to other States starting with 2001 model year vehicles. The EPA rule is effective on 10/15/99. An overview of the National LEV Program; administrative requirements; and amendments to 40 CFR Part 52 are discussed.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Promoting powershift.
Abstract: Energy Efficient Powershift method is the UK government's initiative to kick-start the market for clean fuel vehicles that offers grants to offset the cost of converting new fleet vehicles to cleaner fuels such as LPG, natural gas and electricity. This was improved by a further £3.3 million funding from the Department of Environment, Transport, and Regions. The initiative stimulated orders worth £60 million for such vehicles in its first three years, which contributed to the reduction of 39,000 tons carbon dioxide emissions equivalent to taking 18,000 cars off the road for one year. The method is managed by the Energy Saving Trust and supported by vehicle manufacturers and fuel suppliers.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Fuel oxygenates like methyl-tert-butyl ether (MTBE) and ethanol do less to reduce ozone pollution
Abstract: The National Research Council report, 'Ozone-Forming Potential of Reformulated Gasoline,' states that fuel oxygenates like MTBE and ethanol are less effective in reducing ozone pollution compared with better emissions control equipment, required reduction in sulfur content and controls on evaporative emissions from vehicle gasoline. The report provides an overview of the country's reformulated gasoline program and concludes that the EPA should evaluate carbon monoxide emissions, which can be a significant factor in ozone formation.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Gas technologies give electric utilities cleaner emissions
Abstract: BG&E, PSEG, Duquesne Light, and Conectiv have installed natural gas reburn systems that are expected to drastically reduce NOx emissions from coal-fired electric generation boilers at their respective power plants. The technologies, developed and licensed by the Gas Research Institute, will allow the four mid-Atlantic utilities to reduce NOx emissions during peak period of high temperatures while meeting the heavy seasonal cooling demand. The Phase II reductions commenced on 5/1/99 in the Ozone Transport Region that extends from northern Virginia to Maine. The technologies inject up to 25% of total energy input as natural gas above the furnace's main combustion zone to reduce NOx by ~ 60%.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: World Refining Headline News: Government plans slammed by Peru energy group
Abstract: The National Oil and Mining Society, Peru's top energy business lobby group, criticized the government for what it claims as too much interference in the upcoming privatization of Latin America's largest natural gas project. The criticism added to growing worries that Peru could fail anew to find firms willing to develop and distribute gas from the huge Camisea reserves in what could be Peru's largest foreign investment project at >$2 billion. According to the energy group's president, Augusto Baertl, the scheme is highly state-controlled and undermines the way the private sector does business. Claiming that the terms of the sale later this year were politically and not economically motivated, Baertl said plans to create cheap electricity by setting price limits for the gas would distort free-market competition in the sector. Macroeconomic analysts had also warned that the sale could fail due to the small gas market. Camisea is considered a key factor in driving Peru's economic growth as it will supply industry with cheap energy, provide up to $6 billion in tax revenues, and make Peru a net hydrocarbon exporter. It is projected to start piping ~500 million cu ft/day of natural gas ~310 mi (500 km) to Lima in 2003. Some 20 firms, including leading US, European, and Latin American hydrocarbon companies, have bought government data packages to study whether or not to bid in the new sale.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: SPE Eastern Regional Meeting
Abstract: The proceedings contain 25 papers. The topics discussed include: analysis of worldwide natural gas production; case history: automation system increases production and enhances well safety in the Ramos gas field in Argentina; case history: carbon dioxide foam stimulates Rome in eastern Kentucky; case study: coalbed methane automation system for river gas corporation; coiled tubing conveyed fracture treatments: evolution, methodology and field application; and development of reservoir characterization models using core, well log, and 3D seismic data and intelligent software.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Spotlight: Azerbaijan.
Abstract: As of mid-1998, Azerbaijan had a population of 7.7 million people residing in a land area of 33,436 square miles. There were 17 births and 6 deaths per 1000 population, as well as 19 infant deaths for every 1000 live births, and a population growing in size at 1.1% annually. The average woman had 2.1 births during her reproductive lifetime and life expectancy was 67 years for men and 74 years for women. Azerbaijan is an oil-producing country, although the agricultural sector is responsible for 25% of gross domestic product and employs 31% of the work force. Despite its oil wealth and strong agricultural and mining sectors, Azerbaijan is struggling to improve its environmental conditions and support a large refugee population. The country's air, water, and soil are severely polluted. Air pollution stems from petrochemical plants, refineries, exhaust fumes, and the burning of untreated garbage; water pollution is the result of oil spills, leaky pipelines and tanks, runoff of fertilizers and pesticides, and improperly treated sewage; and land pollution is due to inadequate waste management. The high incidence of waterborne diseases, including cholera, in Azerbaijan is caused by the inadequate treatment of drinking water and sewage intrusion into leaky distribution pipes. Although over 90% of infants under age 1 year are immunized against diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus, polio, and measles, babies in Azerbaijan are 3 times as likely to die before reaching age 1 year than are babies in the US. Azerbaijani children are 5 times more likely to die by age 5 than are US children. Living conditions are especially difficult for the 12% of the overall population which are refugees.
Index Keywords: article; Asia; Azerbaijan; Child Survival; Demographic Factors; demography; developed country; environment; environmental degradation; fertility; infant mortality; Length Of Life; life expectancy; longevity; Migrants; migration; mortality; New Independent States; pollution; population; population density; population dynamics; population growth; population size; refugee; survival rate; Survivorship; Western Asia; Asia; Azerbaijan; Child Survival; Demographic Factors; Developed Countries; Environment; Environmental Degradation; Environmental Pollution; Fertility; Length Of Life; Life Expectancy; Migrants; Migration; Mortality; New Independent States; Population; Population Dynamics; Population Growth; Population Size; Refugees; Survivorship; Western Asia; Asia; Asia, Western; Azerbaijan; Demography; Developed Countries; Emigration and Immigration; Environment; Environmental Pollution; Fertility; Infant Mortality; Life Expectancy; Longevity; Mortality; Population; Population Density; Population Dynamics; Population Growth; Refugees; Survival Rate; Transients and Migrants

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Early action on climate change.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: article; environmental health; greenhouse effect; international cooperation; standard; United States; Environmental Health; Greenhouse Effect; International Cooperation; United States

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: EPA laboratory evaluation of petroMoly HP motor oil
Abstract: Independent laboratory testing of two different vehicles demonstrated an improvement of 4-5% and 2-3% in the city and highway driving tests, respectively, associated with PetroMoly HP 5W-30 motor oil (designated as PetroMoly), a product of Worldwide PetroMoly Corp. The company describes their product as a high performance oil, which, when utilized as a substitute for a conventional motor oil, offers ″increased fuel economy ≤ 10% and reduced toxic emissions ≤ 60%″, in addition to other claimed benefits. EPA analysis of these data showed that the improvements were statistically significant. The improvements in fuel economy appear to be retained for at least some short period after PetroMoly is replaced with a commercial engine oil. One of the two vehicles also showed a 13% reduction in NOx. Although EPA testing showed reductions of 9 and 10% in hydrocarbon and CO exhaust emissions, respectively, these were not statistically significant. Fuel economy improvements were not as large as those measured by an independent laboratory for WorldWide PetroMoly. With the exception of NOx, changes in exhaust emissions were not significant. On the vehicle tested by EPA, a statistically significant NOx penalty of 5% was obtained. A statistically significant NOx reduction of 13% was measured on one of the two vehicles tested by an independent laboratory for the company.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Thorough process analysis significantly reduces methylene chloride emissions
Abstract: Among the many hazardous air pollutants regulated under Title III of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, methylene chloride (also known as dichloromethane) is one of the most widely used. Recently, a team of Eli Lilly and Company engineers assembled to identify and eliminate methylene chloride emissions at their Indiana manufacturing facility. The details of their plant-wide effort are the topic of the article that begins on PAGE 1.22.The team of engineers at Eli Lilly and Company assembled to identify and eliminate methylene chloride emission sources at their Clinton, Indiana manufacturing facility. The team evaluated currently used control technologies and implemented some innovative methods to minimize volatile organic compounds emissions at its facilities.
Index Keywords: Chlorine compounds; Gas emissions; Industrial emissions; Technology transfer; Volatile organic compounds; Methylene chloride; Air pollution control; atmospheric pollution; emission control; industrial emission; United States
